Fields.DialogueText: Lady Hood. Any chance I could get my watch back? It's something that-
They're late! Look at the time...
Who's late?
The seaman I sent to fetch me the latest issue of Harper's Bazaar Magazine.

Fields.MenuText: What's Harper's Bazaar?
I don't care about Harper, or his Bazaar...
Okay. Fine. Can I have my watch back?

Fields.DialogueText: Only the greatest fashion and couture magazine! It's what all the Hollywood movie stars read.
How on earth are you going to keep up appearances, Captain? First impressions count for everything, and we better be in ship-shape.
Not until the seaman comes back with the issue.
Uh-huh. Thank you for that. I need my watch.
Only if you ask properly, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: If my watch is of no further use to you, Lady Hood, might you allow me to relieve you of its weight?
Can I please have my watch back now?
Give. Me. My. Damn. Watch.

Fields.DialogueText: Excellent job in requesting your time piece back, Captain. Though I'm not sure its weight is really the most pressing...
You MAY NOT have it back. That was a dreadful job. Try it again.
*withering glare*
*sigh* I have no time for lessons, here is your watch back, Captain. There are Morganas encroaching.
Harper's Bazaar must wait as well.
I'd like to see them try to get in between Harper and myself!
@BATTLE
Captain! Look here!
I see, yes, a magazine.
Not just any old magazine, it's Harper's Bazaar.
That's it, huh?
Do you have a problem with it, Captain?
Given how determined you were to see it, I half expected you to be on the cover.
For now, my interest is in the content. Look at all these photographs, Captain!

Fields.MenuText: I thought you had more refined tastes than that.
It's not very practical for combat.
I have to ask. Why do you find Hollywood so appealing?

Fields.DialogueText: I would like to see you try with a more refined gown, Captain. Educate me.
Being able to stun the enemy with beauty is the most practical way to do battle, Captain.
The lights, the glamour, the beautiful people on screen. It all seems nearly magical.
*ALARM*
Ugh. I just started reading this magazine. It seems that's how it always goes.
I think...
No time for input, Captain. I have battles to win.
@BATTLE
Oh, they've asked, but they insist on haggling on fees. I can wait them out.
Ah! Peek over at this gown. I'd be keen to wear something like that.
Captain! Captain!
What is it now, Lady Hood?
I have something to show you! I need this. It calls to me.

Fields.MenuText: This had better be important... I have things to do, battles to fight.
It calls to you?
Okay, what is it?

Fields.DialogueText: What isn't important when a lady shows interest in it? Do try to keep up.
Yes! This is the biggest ship in the entire Royal Navy, and certainly the most beautiful, Captain. You can draw your attention away from whatever you're doing for a short time.
That's the spirit, Captain!
Look at this article! It's about Don the Beachcomber. Isn't it marvelous? I want to lounge under the Pacific sun with rum rhapsodies in hand.
I have no clue who Don the Beachcomber is. I can see the general appeal of "rum rhapsodies," but-
Don the Beachcomber sailed all over the South Pacific and Caribbean. He opened a Polynesian style bar in Hollywood. They serve drinks called rum rhapsodies.

Fields.MenuText: That seems fun.
Duly noted. Now we never have to talk about this again!
Okay, you had me at rum.

Fields.DialogueText: Right you are, Captain. And I want to host a party with a Pacific theme. That glorious spotlight will shine down on me as if I were a Hollywood star.
Things aren't always about you, Captain. I'm talking about the well-being of the crew you are responsible for. And the crew demands rum rhapsodies.
Brilliant! I want to host a party with a Pacific theme. That glorious spotlight will shine down on me as if I were a Hollywood star.
I've determined that in order to get the rum, we must head to the Caribbean. A substation simply won't do.
*ALARM*
Drat, what horrid creatures! Time to put our heads down and muddle through.
@BATTLE
Do they, now?
If not right now, I can convince them faster than a dock worker puffing a ciggy.
Ah. Pardon me - of course you wouldn't be in the know.
A "dock worker puffing a ciggy" is a metaphor for speed, now?
Yes. Hush.
What?
I don't even know where to begin.
Look at these palms! Oh! Look at these banana drinks! We'll have to pop right over to Panama after we're done in the Caribbean.
Point two. What's in Panama?
The bananas. I haven't been to Panama since I was on tour. What a grand time that was... it will be fascinating to see how much has changed since then.
It seems that you're planning an entire tour.
One must have a hobby.
I thought you didn't have any hobbies?
That's rather short-sighted, Captain. In case you haven't noticed, being beautiful is a full-time job. My time for hobbies can be limited, as there are only twenty-four hours in a day.
How so?
There's eating right, exercising, learning about the latest trends and makeup, styling my hair, coordinating outfits....
I see.
In short, being attractive is what I'm good at, and I plan on being top in my field. Pandering to the crew with a rum bar is one way to boost morale.

Fields.MenuText: I don't know if the influence of grog would make you more attractive to the crew.
Just rum?
Is there going to be grilled pineapple?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not sure if that's supposed to be an insult or a compliment...
I'm sure we can find other libations if rum isn't quite your taste.
Now that you mention it, yes! Keep up with the good ideas, Captain.
*ALARM*
It simply never fails... I'll take care of this and be back in time for tea.
@BATTLE
Two points. One - I'm reasonably confident that your fixation with rum started with you finding out before I did that we've been ordered to the West Indies.
If not, though, don't think we're going there just because you said so.
I understand you have to think that to protect your self-esteem, and I'll try to respect it.
Uh-huh.
Baaa!
Hood! I thought you got rid of those sheep!
I thought we went over this, Captain, it's Lady Hood. Now again, from the top.
Lady Hood, I thought the sheep were gone long ago.
The baaing you hear? Those aren't any sheep I've put on the ship - but now that you bring it up, we should get some...
No sheep! Where is that noise coming from?
Sheep are quite popular here as fatstock. Granted, they are sleek and not wooly, so many people mistake them for goats. This particular breed originally comes from West Africa.

Fields.MenuText: Don't get any more sheep. And unload our dignitaries as soon as possible.
Listen, for the record, I don't object to a few sheep if they make you happy.
How do the cats feel about our honored guests?

Fields.DialogueText: If you say so, Captain. Although the crew might sleep better at night with a few to count.
Perhaps later on, Captain. I haven't been paying as much attention as I should to Ginger and Fishcakes, they need some attention.
Oh, they're delighted in their catty way. And thank you for reminding me - I need to see if they're still in the mess or galley. Maybe they need some Oyster Kirkpatrick or shrimp.
When is the rum getting here?
I dispatched a team earlier, right when we arrived in port. They should arrive back with crates shortly.
Crates?
You can't expect the largest and most beautiful ship in the fleet to throw a Polynesian party with only a few bottles of rum. Everything here is bought in bulk.
You certainly like to do everything on a grand scale.
*ALARM*
Battles included.
@BATTLE
They're guests. Dignitaries.
Pardon me?
We've agreed to transport certain dignitaries in exchange for a favour or two. Nothing you need to worry about.
... And a layperson might mistake these dignitaries for sheep?
Quite easily, I should think.
Baa!
I feel a headache coming on.
Since we're on the subject...
Now that we have the rum, next stop is Panama for bananas. Maybe we should also pick up some macaw feathers. Although, perhaps Costa Rica is better suited for that.
What do you need parrot feathers for?
To adorn my outfit. I want to stick with a tropical theme. They might also look dashing as a centerpiece on the tables. Oh yes, we will need tablecloths, I want a grass hut look for those.
You don't feel that all of this is, perhaps, just a little too much?
Don the Beachcomber is very popular bar in Hollywood. Watch, Captain, it won't be long until the United Kingdom catches on.

Fields.MenuText: I don't see how this will catch on.
Why don't we go back to Europe? Think of all the delicious grog there!
I'm looking forward to the event.

Fields.DialogueText: Exotic rum rhapsodies, cove-like ambiance. What's not to like?
If you're trying to manipulate me, it's a poor attempt, Captain.
I'm surprised, Captain. Keep it up and I might let you share some of the spotlight with yours truly.
*ALARM*
Come now, Captain. Let's see to these bothers.
Uh-huh. It's very daring of you to do it without parrot feathers on.
@BATTLE
Hush.
*meow*
There you are, Fishcakes! I've been looking for you. Yes, your bed in our powder room is so comfortable, isn't it? Only the best for you, and your bunkmate Ginger, of course.
Lady Hood! I need you!
I'm in my powder room, Captain. You may enter.
The crew is saying something about you wanting a swizzle...?
Ah, yes! The rum swizzle, a popular Caribbean drink. You put ice into an electric blender and mix with rum and fruit. It's similar to a mint julep.

Fields.MenuText: Okay. That's considerably less disturbing than some of the other things I thought a swizzle might be.
How do you know so much about the Caribbean?
It appears that you've found the cats.

Fields.DialogueText: At least you're finally using your imagination!
Scots have had a foothold in the Caribbean for some time now.
They know where the most comfortable place on the ship is.
So, as long as we're on the general subject of things I'm probably happier not knowing... you've been saying your end result is some kind of Caribbean-South Pacific fusion, right?
Correct! Don the Beachcomber blends the two. The drinks are Caribbean in nature but the decorations are more Polynesian.
But enough small talk! There's work to be done and I still need to order swizzle cups. Look sharp!
@BATTLE
Captain, look - it's the chough float I rode on for the grand opening of my water closet and powder room.
... Do I want to know where you've been storing it?
No, you do not. Good question, though.

Fields.MenuText: Is there going to be a parade for the rum rhapsody party?
And, for the record, I will note that that was not a sentence I ever expected to say on the deck of a ship in my command.
That's still one impressive bird.

Fields.DialogueText: Not this time, Captain. But it does inspire me to consider it for the future.
It's always good to expand one's experiences and become more cultured.
It's why I've kept the float, a fine example of artisan work.
At any rate, I think It will be important to incorporate this float into the party theme, somehow.
How will the crew feel about a giant bird looming overhead?
That's it!
A looming bird?
We'll put a thatched grass canopy in the beak. It will look like the chough is holding up a canopy over the tables! Perfect idea, Captain - you've been as sharp as a tack lately!

Fields.MenuText: Yeah... that's what I intended.
Sure, but that's not exactly what I was getting at.

Fields.DialogueText: Excellent job, Captain. Keep it up. Sometimes inspiration can come when least expected.
That's how inspiration comes, suddenly and when least expected.
*ALARM*
These Morganas, however, are always expected.
@BATTLE
Right. You can assume we'll revisit the subject the next time somebody tells me we don't have space to store extra blankets.
If you order higher quality blankets next time, I promise you I'll find room.
*sigh* Okay, so, I'm looking at a parade float.
Captain, we've been offered a mission near New Zealand and we have to accept it.
I'm going to take it as a given that you're primarily motivated by the strategic value of the action under discussion.
One has to seize every opportunity, Captain. I need jade Maori jewelry for the rum rhapsody night. Granted that color doesn't quite compliment my eyes, but when in Rome...

Fields.MenuText: Of course, more jewelry!
I salute you for making the most of a significant detour, I guess.
Have any plans for food?

Fields.DialogueText: Why not? One can never have enough adornments.
Oh, my Caribbean pursuits were basically already done. And after New Zealand we might head over to Goa. I need palm fronds and coconuts.
Possibly lots of lamb and fish for meat dishes.
Oh, and I can't forget those grilled pineapples.

Fields.MenuText: ... I do like pineapples.
Pineapples don't suit my palate.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, then it should be a night you should mark on your calendar, Captain.
Perhaps you should educate your palate, Captain. Pineapple is the king of fruit.
This certainly sounds like it will be an exotic evening.
It will be a grand evening, the likes of which the crew will remember for many years to come.
*ALARM*
Hopefully, the crew will remember more of the party, and less of these beasts.
@BATTLE
Of course.
I'm guessing that there's also a way to make this benefit your party plans.
It's for the...? Huh.
Is that clashing jade color too much after all?
That's a blow, Captain. No, I've received word that poachers have been collecting choughs off the seaside of Cornwall. It's appalling!
Okay. Agreed. I'm curious to hear how you plan to deter them, though. You can't exactly bombard Penzance to scare off poachers.
Yes, I've been pondering what to do. My solution is that we use decoys.

Fields.MenuText: Tell me you don't mean... Lady Hood, that statue is fifteen feet high.
What are you going to make the decoys out of?
How many decoys do you need?

Fields.DialogueText: You haven't heard my plan yet, Captain. And over the ocean, the vastness can play tricks on you.
Probably some black chicken feathers. The more realistic looking they are, the better. We have a crew of over 1400 men, we can create some decoys in no time.
At least thirty, Captain, to make a honey pot trap for the poachers.
Okay, let's hear this plan.
We don't need to use the statue. Instead we can create several decoys on a section uninhabited by the birds. We then wait for the poachers to approach.
How do we catch them?
They'll most likely be in their boats since it's easy to move up and down the coast and scan from a distance. Think of it like hunting the Morganas.
It's worth noting that if they're going by sea, the poachers are actually at risk from the Morganas.
My heart just bleeds for them. Truly.
*ALARM*
Well, let's practice a bit on these Morganas, shall we?
@BATTLE

I hate to disappoint you, but our New Zealand operation is on hold. The Morganas just made a push on Scapa Flow. They were pushed back, but London wants Royal Navy ships in British waters for a while.
I understand. And it's for the best.
The sooner we get to Cornwall, the better. If it isn't one thing, it's always another. Being beautiful is so challenging at times.
How is being beautiful related to any of this at all?
You wouldn't understand, Captain.
I'm not quite sure how to respond to that.
Beauty stuns, Captain. And such a response presents an excellent opening for an attack.

Fields.MenuText: Like an ambush?
Don't take this the wrong way, but subjective aesthetic sense isn't exactly the most reliable foundation for military strategy.
What about the birds? Choughs are extremely rare as it is.

Fields.DialogueText: Exactly, Captain!
I don't understand how you can be so narrow-minded at times. I've just thoroughly explained.
Therefore, we must be diligent in saving them, Captain.
However, it's time to surprise the enemy that is approaching our ship.
Is it possible to surprise an enemy that knows your location?
If they're not expecting beauty at the bow, then yes, it is. Observe and take note, Captain.
@BATTLE
We've reached the Isle of Man?
Correct, Captain. This is where the poachers were reportedly headed, and where many choughs nest.
If these birds are rare, wouldn't a honeypot decoy seem suspicious?
Perhaps, but if you see a ship inspecting the decoys, then you're probably right to suspect that it's them. Lieutenant!
Yes, Lady Hood?
Have our seaman dispatch the decoys along the cliffs. Make sure they are realistically spaced. We want to fool them just long enough to be caught.

Fields.MenuText: So, what if they're just bird watching?
I don't have to remind you that reports from Blackpool have a significant Morgana force headed our way.
How many decoys are there?

Fields.DialogueText: That's why we hold the ship and call the constable. If they are poachers, they'll have evidence on their boat.
We're quite capable of dealing with both problems. This is a testament to the Mighty Hood's dedication to her country, Captain.
The crew and myself have agreed that five choughs were enough to garner the attention of any poachers.
The crew is being dispatched now, Lady Hood - but scouts have found the Morgana fleet, Captain.
Right.
Actually, this is good. If we're engaged, the poachers won't think a thing of seeing a battleship on the western coast of England.
@BATTLE
Um...
Go ahead, Lieutenant.
Aye aye!
If the poachers were in the habit of thinking, they wouldn't be risking their necks in the middle of a Morgana assault in the first place.
Legitimate point. You really are earning your keep these days!
Thank you for that. Really.
Excuse me, Captain, have you seen Lady Hood?
Have you checked her bathroom?
She wasn't in her powder room, Captain.
I thought my ears were burning. What news?
The decoys were a success, Lady Hood. A suspicious boat tolling the area has been captured and we are waiting for the constables to arrive.
Brilliant! Well done, Lieutenant! This rum rhapsody party will surely pay you back a thousandfold for all your hard work - but, in the meantime, you deserve a kiss as a token of my appreciation.
You better get out of here before she asks you to go steady, Lieutenant.
I still can't believe that you're not more respectful of my charms, Captain. Honestly, do you have some secret shield on under your clothes?

Fields.MenuText: Yes, I wear leaded clothing as a fashion statement.
No, just common sense.
Do you treat every crew member like that?

Fields.DialogueText: I have absolutely no clue where you got that idea from. What magazines are you reading, Captain?
I promise you, that's not a common reaction at all.
Only the ones who show admiration. It's their admiration which makes a ship like myself so beautiful. If no one admires you, are you truly attractive?
*ALARM*
Ha! We'll be dealing with the wretched things just as the constables show up. How splendid we'll seem to them!
I'm starting to wonder what your motive is.
@BATTLE
Captain. Ma'am.
Oh. I... uh... is there anything else I can do for you, then, Lady Hood? Anything at all?
It has been confirmed by the authorities, Lady Hood, that there was evidence of poaching on board that boat.
Wasn't that something, Captain? The looks on the constables' faces when they realized a Belle caught the poachers?
You might want to share the credit. The crew made the decoys and set them out.
The crew will have the great pleasure of seeing their lady in the headlines. After all, one can't be a celebrity without admirers.

Fields.MenuText: There are going to be headlines over birds?
How many admirers do you have?
Is the party going to include these headlines?

Fields.DialogueText: You made note and reference of how rare these birds were, Captain. I don't see why there shouldn't be a headline, especially considering my involvement.
Numbers and finite details are so hard to keep track of when you have the crew the size of a city to manage.
The chough float holding the overhang will now certainly be the centerpiece. I think I'll dedicate the party to the chough, in fact.
There go the constables' boats with the suspects on board. So that's... where are you going, Lady Hood?
To get ready for my interviews with the press - didn't the Lieutenant tell you?
Captain, I'm here...
Thank you, Ensign. I've already been informed about the press.
Isn't Lady Hood incredible? Always so punctual.
You'll go far, my friend. You know how to talk to a lady.
*ALARM*
Finally, something I can focus on!
@BATTLE
Would you look at that! Making the front page of the newspaper, Lady Hood!
Isn't it something, Captain? My likeness across all of England. Everyone who reads the paper today will see my face and say to themselves, "Lady Hood is stunning."
But, of course, you did it for the birds.
No, I really did! They're on the Cornwall Coat of Arms, Captain! That makes them my responsibility - just like if Ginger and Fishcakes were in trouble, I wouldn't hesitate to rescue my darlings.

Fields.MenuText: Uh-huh. And if someone suggested you rescued the birds solely for the fame?
You do have feelings for something besides yourself after all!
Huh. I apologize for suggesting otherwise.

Fields.DialogueText: Quite the opposite, Captain!
Why would you even question that, Captain? Remember, I eat meals in the mess every day and entertain the sailors aboard. Spirits must be kept high.
As well you should! My goodness, Captain, a little awareness of the responsibilities of your position, please!
Well, I best get ready for my interview. Someone from the BBC Home Service is coming to interview me, and I need to look my very best!
It's a radio interview.
My beauty is not bound by the limitations of radio frequencies.
*ALARM*
Well, it looks as if there are Morganas to deal with now.
Think of the newspaper headlines! "Lady Hood Victorious Over Poachers and Morganas!"
@BATTLE
That, finally, is the last of the press. I can't believe I'm saying this, but I'm glad that we can go back to focusing on the party - and whatever else passes for normal around here.
How delightful, Captain! Those words are music to my ears. We're headed to Goa next.
Okay. I'll ask. What's in Goa?
The coconuts, palm fronds and wicker chairs for the party.

Fields.MenuText: Couldn't you have picked those up in the Caribbean?
But you can't leave the ship to get to the beach...
Are coconuts your favorite food?

Fields.DialogueText: And miss out on the opportunity to see the lovely beaches of Goa?
That is why I must live vicariously through my crew, Captain.
While I am fond of the coconut, I find that I enjoy strawberries the best. Chocolate covered strawberries are a dessert of grand opulence.
I'm taking an educated guess here, but I'm thinking that the watchword here is "refinement."
You're doing so well, Captain!
Ah. We're back to the Maori jade.
And culture! I'm sure our crew will be fascinated by the tattooing on the Maori people.
Don't tell me you're thinking of-
Oh, goodness no! I appreciate the audacity of the statement a good tattoo can make, but I simply cannot risk altering my perfect complexion.
*ALARM*
We certainly can't have Morganas risk my complexion either, but I am ever so worried about the grey hairs that might come as a result of this. Especially at my age.
What age is that?
Don't be vulgar, Captain.
@BATTLE
I know. I signed the orders.
*sigh*
Thanks for that.
You're quite welcome. Now, do keep your eyes open for assignments that could put us at New Zealand after Goa - we can't leave our work half-finished.
Huh.
Lady Hood, what are you looking at so intently?
I'm watching the crew enjoying themselves on the beach...

Fields.MenuText: By which you mean the... more athletic gentlemen over there?
What are they doing now?
Would you consider this a beautiful beach?

Fields.DialogueText: Why not? The Mighty Hood knows how to utilize all of her resources.
They were playing rugby, but it seems they have stopped for a bit of a rest.
This is indeed a very beautiful beach, Captain. It more than deserves its reputation.
Where are the coconuts and palm fronds?
I had an seaman go retrieve them. They should be back soon enough.
Were you able to negotiate a lower price for the coconuts?
That's a rather interesting question, Captain. As it turns out, you pay the man in coconuts. He climbs the tree to get coconuts, but in turn, you pay him in coconuts.
I know, it's all needlessly complicated.
Okay... what about the palm fronds?
Really, Captain! The coconut man can just hack down some branches. It saves time. Not everything has to be dramatically done.
The palm trees and coconuts are here, Lady Hood.
*ALARM*
How terribly dreadful, I'm going to have to miss the next rugby match.
@BATTLE
Why is there a jungle on deck, Lady Hood?
These are the palm fronds I requested for the party, Captain.
These are potted palm trees! I thought you were getting a few branches.
I thought about branches, but decided that was too boring. We can take spliced electrical cords adorned with light bulbs and string them between the trees.
Like holiday lights?
In theory, but more glamourous. Bigger lights, like in Hollywood.

Fields.MenuText: Of course, just like Hollywood. The crew can put their handprints in the cement!
I think holiday lights are better.
Why not decorate the chough float in lights?

Fields.DialogueText: I can't tell if you are being sarcastic or not, Captain...
If you think they'd be better, we can string some under the chough pavilion. Oh, what a lovely title, "Rum Rhapsodies Under the Chough Pavilion!"
That's a rather good suggestion for the evening hours, Captain!
Do these trees make you feel claustrophobic at all?
Not at all - I'm perfectly comfortable in the midst of any beauty, whether it be small or large.
*ALARM*
What do you suspect the Morganas will think?
I suspect they won't care whether we have a tropical forest on deck. They'll want to sink us all the same.
@BATTLE
I know I'm going to regret asking, but...
Just look at all this jade. Isn't it exquisite, Captain?
There certainly is a lot of it on display. This is for you to choose from, right? You didn't buy it all?
Ah, Captain - consider all the time that went into acquiring these precious stones!
First reassure me that I'm not going to stumble into a giant hole in the ship's discretionary funds next time I look.
I think you're onto something there, Captain.
It's fascinating how much appreciation you're capable of showing... when you're focused on something you consider beautiful.
There is a wide range of things I consider beautiful, Captain. My crew is one.
Huh. I didn't see that one coming.
When you are beautiful, you can take anyone by surprise, even the captain of the ship.

Fields.MenuText: Why am I not surprised?
You enjoy being in the spotlight. It's fascinating to see your caring side.
I'm just going to sit here and smile out of not knowing what to do.

Fields.DialogueText: If that's an attempt at humor, then it wasn't very effective.
Being in the spotlight is the perfect opportunity to showcase philanthropy.
That is the first step to utilizing beauty, to take everything with grace.
*ALARM*
Should we take these Morganas with grace?
Everything can be done with grace - even dealing with these wretches.
@BATTLE
How your concerns can be so bourgeois in the face of this loveliness...
I know. There's really no hope for me at all. But-?
No official moneys have been or will be waylaid, Captain. On my honour.
Then I can say without reservation that this is spectacular. The people responsible - the ones who put in those hours - accomplished something magnificent.
No, no. At the moment it's all still the property of that excited-looking gentleman over there.
Wait, why is all the jade still here?
I couldn't decide on what pieces to wear, and thought that I might as well buy it all and decide later.
... You're kidding.
Well, what if the crew wanted to wear jade? You know, get into the spirit of things.

Fields.MenuText: All of the crew?
And I assume you're also thinking of the cats.
But what about after the party?

Fields.DialogueText: High fashion knows no boundaries, Captain.
Oh, certainly! I'm fashioning little collars made with jade facets for Ginger and Fishcakes. I think they'll come to appreciate them in time.
Think of how much grog we can trade for this jade. I'm sure the crew won't disagree with this philosophy, Captain.
About the party - remind me to make sure that Ginger and Fishcakes are aware what time it starts.
Do the cats honestly care about the party?
If it involves shrimp cocktail, then yes, they would. You can't have a party on the Mighty Hood and not have the mascots present - that's breaking a sacred rule.
*ALARM*
I certainly hope the Morganas aren't fond of shrimp cocktail.
@BATTLE
Put those trees in that grouping over there! Officer, hang those lights under the thatched pavilion.
This is going to be fairly impressive, isn't it? I knew you were aiming high, but once you actually see it all coming together...
Quite! There is still so much to do, though - and the newspapers still need to be contacted.
Newspapers? There weren't even any newspapers for when the washroom opened...
These are the same newspaper and radio broadcasters from the chough heist. It's all about who you know, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Why not? It's as good of a reason to get back in the spotlight.
What's the drink list?
How much do you intend to drink during the party?

Fields.DialogueText: Speaking of spotlight, I still need to pick a color palette and a hairstyle for the party. I'm bringing aboard a certain stylist from Hollywood. I have to be discreet, but I'm sure you'd know the name.
A lot of rum. Lots of iced blended drinks served in swizzle cups with fruit garnishes.
If I showed restraint, then it would be about a third of my body weight, Captain. As much as necessary, Captain.
I do have a question, Captain...
What's that?
If the jade is green, my hair is strawberry blonde and my eyes are rossé, what color should my outfit be?

Fields.MenuText: Gold.
Blue.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I hadn't thought about that! Excellent choice, Captain.
Blue? That seems like a lot of contrasting colors. I don't know if that would bring out my fair completion.
*ALARM*
Well for now, it's your battle dress.
What color should the sequins be? Red for battle or black for warning?
@BATTLE
Hood! Things are getting crazy out there!
Then it's time for this lady to make her grand entrance.
... You mean live birds, don't you? Not just recordings for atmosphere, but live tropical birds.
Don't forget, I did have a parrot as a mascot at one point in time. Just make sure my darlings don't decide to give chase.
LADY HOOD! LADY HOOD!

Fields.MenuText: I honestly can't believe this is happening. Adoring fans... I thought it was just an exaggeration.
You would think we were in a movie, with all the fanfare and cheering crowds.
How many press types are here?

Fields.DialogueText: Well, can you blame them? Their hope for peace also happens to be the largest and most beautiful ship in the United Kingdom.
Glamorous people attract glamorous lifestyles.
There are at least two journalists as well as a radio broadcaster.
Lady Hood, your cats.
Let's go, my darlings - out to meet our adoring fans. Take a deep breath and put on your best faces.
You're talking to the cats and not to me, right?
If the advice applies, Captain....
@BATTLE
Uh-huh. What are those bird noises?
Oh, the macaws, I should think.
What's this?  That swizzy drink you were talking about?
Correct, Captain!
What does it taste like?
That's the mystery! You'll have to find out.
*takes a swig*
It tastes... like pineapple, and coconut. I taste those fresh coconuts we got in Goa.
Isn't it wonderful, Captain? You should try the rum and cherry.
Hmm... shaved ice and a lot of fruit. I can certainly see people also drinking this on a hot day.
Well, it's time for a ciggy, can you hand me my clutch? My case should be in your jacket pocket.
Wait... it is! How...?
Your jacket has pockets, mine does not. I slipped it in when you weren't looking.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not your walking purse.
Am I your walking purse now?
Why are there extra pockets in my jacket?

Fields.DialogueText: I don't have enough hands to look fashionable while smoking, drinking, and carrying a clutch.
It's a fashion trend I am hoping to start. The press is here, and I'm hoping to see a blurb about it in Harper's Bazaar.
I had the tailor install them. It's so you can carry my accessories.
*brings an unlit cigarette to her mouth*
Well...?

Fields.MenuText: Sorry, I don't smoke. No lighter, no matches.
Oh, yes!

Fields.DialogueText: Officer! Be a darling!
Thank you, Captain.
*ALARM*
*collective exasperated sigh*
*puts out cigarette*
Figures that they would try to spoil our fun. What do you say crew? Let's show the Bitch Fleet what the Mighty Hood is of!
@BATTLE
Listen, friends! Listen!
Quiet down! I think our Belle is about to be inspirational!
Thank you, Captain.
Let me just say this-
If we stopped "Rum Rhapsodies Under the Chough Pavilion" now, then the Morganas would win this day. We cannot let them strike terror and fear into our hearts!
Embrace the moment! Party in defiance!
You're the best damn crew in the world!
*APPLAUSE*

Fields.MenuText: That was a compelling speech.
Nice speech - but I need you to be ready. You know as well as I do that the noise will attract Morgana attention.
Is the press still here?

Fields.DialogueText: It's vital that my speech be as captivating as my appearance.
Of course! And when they come, we do what we always have done - we fight. We fight and then celebrate our victory.
Of course! Think of the headlines, Captain!
Maybe I'll try one of those red drinks?
Right you are, Captain! Watch out though! If you get too close to the palm trees, one of the exotic parrots might bite you.
The parrots are in the palms?
Think of it as an authentic tropical experience. Cold rum drinks, biting parrots hidden in bushes.
*ALARM*
Do Morganas count as the authentic tropical experiences?
They are quite like pirates on the high seas, with their mysterious ships and wild eyes.
@BATTLE
I have a confession to make...
if you do have to confess in private, don't forget about my chapel...
Well, it's more of a profession than a confession.
Then by all means, Captain, profess.

Fields.MenuText: The party was more fun than I was anticipating.
The amount of grog you can drink is impressive.
I might have enjoyed all the attention from the press.

Fields.DialogueText: I should certainly hope so. Are you sure you're not wearing a charm that makes you immune to my influence?
When you live with sailors, you come up with creative ways to earn their respect. Beauty will garner their attention, but the grog will earn their respect.
Isn't it such a thrill, Captain?
Well, that's my profession.
Best to get it off your conscience. I must confess though...
What is it you need to confess?
Now that the preparations for the party are over, I can finally let my hair down and enjoy some grog.
What do you mean?
Come see, half of my vanity is secretly storing grog. Sort of like a speakeasy in the States.
... You somehow continue to surprise, Lady Hood.
You know you're happy to have me on board.
You're difficult to keep up with, but that... that much is true.
@BATTLE
